> It is neither A nor B.  The question is h=
ow the very first 
> generation could proceed when there is no information =
about either 
> population to begin with.  Our paper may have omitted this =
detail.
> 
> We used a tournament in one population (say A) to bootstrap th=
e 
> process.  It was basically like a sports championship tournament, 
> w=
here everyone is paired off, and then those who won the first round 
> play=
 against each other, those who won the second round play against 
> each ot=
her, and so on, until the final is between two champs.  That 
> is one reas=
on we used populations of 256 (it is a power of 2).  
> 
> Note that this t=
ournament gives you a rough idea of who is good and 
> who is not in the in=
itial population, which is all you need to get 
> the process rolling.  The=
n fitnesses are assigned to population A 
> based on how well individuals d=
id in the tournament and coevolution 
> proceeds normally from there.
>

ken
